messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
Can you provide insights on the 'Show Your Work: Finish, Polish and Forget It' approach?

The 'Show Your Work: Finish, Polish and Forget It' approach involves several steps to achieve a high-quality dental restoration.

1. Preparation: After anesthetizing the teeth and placing packing cord, the dentist prepares the tooth by removing the old composite and restoring the defect.
2. Adding Composite: The new composite material, such as Omnichroma, is added to the tooth and light-cured.
3. Contouring: The facial surface is smoothed and evenly reduced with a coarse disc, and the initial contouring of the facial and gingival margin is done with a flame-tip diamond bur.
4. Polishing: A polishing cup is used to obtain a high polish, resulting in a natural-looking and smooth restoration.

This approach ensures that the restoration is well-adapted to the tooth, polished, and smooth, which helps prevent plaque accumulation and future issues.

If you have any more questions about this or any other dental topic, feel free to ask.

[Tag: Show Your Work: Finish, Polish and Forget It]

What is Soft-Tissue Contouring?

We use a compound topical     anesthetic (Fig 8) Application     involves placing the patient in cheek     retractors with slow suction to     prevent swallowing of the topical The numbing gel is administered     using a small syringe (Fig 9) along     the gingival margin, left on for     5 minutes, then suctioned off
Need more help? I'm just a message away!
What's next?

The     patient then sits for 5 more minutes Prepare the laser We use the     Spectralase 980, an ultrapulse diode     laser, which requires the patient,     assistants and doctor to all wear     protective eyewear We prepare a cup     of water with microbrushes and a cup     with a diluted solution of hydrogen     peroxide and a toothbrush, and use a     high speed to cut a surgical suction Begin the procedure We typically     perform the contour from second     bicuspid to second bicuspid on the     upper arch, starting with a test spot     in the posterior, then scalloping the     gingival margins
Any other questions? Just ask and I am here to help!
What can you tell me about Soft-Tissue Contouring?

Contact with the     tissue is not necessary; the longer the     laser is held active in a location, the     more tissue that will be removed, so     many times, slow passes accomplish     the most In many cases, it is helpful to debulk     the tissue to aid in proper margin     creation This is done simply by     thinning the tissues and papilla Normally this procedure is done at     the 12 o’clock position Once the     initial pass is complete, it can be     helpful to take a photograph for     evaluation or to approach the patient     from the front to detail the margins     of the incisors
Let me know if you have any other questions!

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
Can you explain Soft-Tissue Contouring?

Soft-Tissue Contouring is a procedure that involves the use of a compound topical anesthetic. The patient is placed in cheek retractors with slow suction to prevent swallowing of the topical. The numbing gel is administered along the gingival margin and left on for 5 minutes before being suctioned off.

Next, the patient sits for 5 more minutes while the laser is prepared. We use the Spectralase 980, an ultrapulse diode laser, which requires protective eyewear for the patient, assistants, and doctor. A cup of water with microbrushes and a cup with a diluted solution of hydrogen peroxide and a toothbrush are prepared.

The procedure is typically performed from second bicuspid to second bicuspid on the upper arch, starting with a test spot in the posterior. The gingival margins are scalloped, and the tissue is debulked to aid in proper margin creation. This is done by thinning the tissues and papilla. The procedure is normally performed at the 12 o’clock position.

After the initial pass, it can be helpful to take a photograph for evaluation or to approach the patient from the front to detail the margins of the incisors.

[Tag: Soft-Tissue Contouring]

chat.topic: Impact Your Patients’ Quality of Life––And Yours
chat.tag: Impact Your Patients’ Quality of Life––And Yours

messages.text: What's the deal with Impact Your Patients’ Quality of Life––And Yours?

You can tell when it happens They walk in with more confidence They seem to stand taller, smile more and of course, give you compliments
If there's more you'd like to learn, feel free to ask!
I'm all ears

I’m talking about your patients Maybe not all of them yet, but the number is growing These are the people whose quality of life you’ve impacted
Hope this answers your question, and I'm here for any more!
Share additional insights

You think it’s about dental hygiene, perio, plaque, calculus, brushing and flossing, but it’s not It’s not about bleeding gums and periodontal disease It’s about making a difference in someone’s life Good oral health allows people to eat, smile, talk and feel confident about themselves and live a life free from oral pain Your dual role as the preventive specialist/periodontal therapist in the office plays an essential part in changing the quality of your patients’ lives Remind yourself of that daily
Let me know if you have any other questions!
Let's talk about Impact Your Patients’ Quality of Life––And Yours?

You know you’ve made a difference by the comments you hear from your patients You can measure the plaque scores, bleeding points, and pocket depths, but it’s what your patients say to you that lets you know you’ve made a difference beyond plaque and gingivitis I’ve asked a few hygienists to tell me about their recent successes and how their dental hygiene skills have made a difference in someone’s life I asked Cori Gwilliam if a particular patient came to mind whose quality of live was changed by her education and treatment She didn’t hesitate "Yes," she said
Hope this answers your question, and I'm here for any more!
Could you provide details on Impact Your Patients’ Quality of Life––And Yours?

"Ralph* "  "Ralph has been a patient in our office for several years, Cori continued "He’s undergone perio surgery before, and has lots of exposed roots with 4-5 mm pockets in the interproximals and two remaining deep furcation areas on the maxillary first molars I dreaded seeing him because I never seemed to have enough time to get the plaque and calculus deposits off The furcation areas were the worst as they were always infected, so I definitely wasn’t effective at cleaning out the plaque and Ralph wasn’t either
Let me know if you have any dental questions and I will be glad to help!

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
What can you tell me about Impact Your Patients’ Quality of Life––And Yours?

Impacting your patients' quality of life means you can see a change in their confidence and overall well-being. You'll notice they stand taller, smile more, and give you compliments. This impact goes beyond dental hygiene and periodontal treatment, focusing on improving their lives and self-confidence. A good example is a patient named Ralph, who underwent perio surgery and had extensive plaque and calculus deposits. After proper treatment and care, his quality of life improved significantly.\n\n[Tag: Impact Your Patients’ Quality of Life––And Yours]

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
Can you provide some insight regarding Craniofacial Implants and Prosthetics?

Craniofacial Implants and Prosthetics are a specialized field in dentistry. I am familiar with the topic as Dr. Vladimir Frias, who has extensive experience in this area. Dr. Frias received his Doctor of Dental Surgery and Master of Science degrees from Columbia University, completing specialty training in prosthodontics. He then completed fellowships in maxillofacial prosthetics and surgical implantology.

Dr. Frias is a diplomate of the American Board of Prosthodontics and has been published in multiple scientific journals in the fields of craniofacial and implant reconstruction. His current research includes 3D printing for craniofacial cellular frameworks. He maintains a private practice in prosthodontics and implant surgery and is the director of maxillofacial prosthetics at the Roswell Park Comprehensive Cancer Center in Buffalo, New York.

[Tag: Craniofacial Implants and Prosthetics]

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
I'd like to learn more about the process of 'Show Your Work: Stacking the Odds for Success' in dentistry.

10) The SDR Flow+ material is used to evenly cure each molar in 10 seconds. It self-levels even upside down in the upper arch for gap-free adaptation. (Fig 7-8)

11) TPH Spectra ST composite Shade A2 is placed as the final layer. Finishing and occlusal interferences are adjusted appropriately to the patient’s occlusion using the one-step Enhance Finishing System for a smooth finish. (Fig 11)

12) The postoperative X-ray shows excellent anatomy and radiopacity of the composite materials. The patient reported that his cold sensitivity had been successfully treated. (Fig 12)

13) The sectional matrix, retaining rings, LED curing light, and one-step finishing system ensure a streamlined workflow for the practitioner and long-lasting results for the patient. This simplifies the Class II procedure without sacrificing quality. (Fig 13)

14) The low film thickness of the bonding agent and excellent cavity adaptation of the bulk-fill flowable are used to reduce sensitivity and ensure a gap-free restoration. (Fig 13-14)

This process aims to make Class II restorations less tedious and time-consuming while ensuring natural aesthetics and high-quality results.

[Tag: New Grad 2023]

chat.topic: A Voice In The Arena: The ‘Not-Enough’ Superpower
chat.tag: A Voice In The Arena: The ‘Not-Enough’ Superpower

messages.text: I'm curious about A Voice In The Arena: The ‘Not-Enough’ Superpower?

by Chad Foster, DDS, MS, editorial director [Editor’s note: For greater context on the theme of this column, check out Dr Chad Foster’s November 2021 column, "Don’t Leave the Parking Brake On," and his July/August 2021 column, "The Wanting Self "] One of the best sports documentaries I’ve ever seen is  The Last Dance, which chronicles Michael Jordan’s NBA career with the Chicago Bulls Growing up a Suns fan, I rooted against Michael Jordan the basketball player, but his personal story through the documentary really connected with me
I'm here to assist with any further dental inquiries.
Please continue

One of the scenes that touched me the most was when Jordan discussed his relationship with his father, James Jordan While Michael Jordan was growing up, his dad would often put him down and belittle him in front of his brothers Jordan didn’t go on a deep introspective dive into the subject, but the rare emotion in his voice when giving brief commentary on his father’s disapproval was telling: "When you’re going through it, it’s traumatic, because … you know, I want that approval, I want that confidence, so my determination got even greater
Let me know if you have any dental questions and I will be glad to help!
Do you have any information regarding A Voice In The Arena: The ‘Not-Enough’ Superpower?

" It was clear that through Jordan’s formative years, he internalized a "chase for enough-ness" in the eyes of the most important man in his world As Jordan’s life played out through the documentary from one achievement to the next during the greatest basketball career of all time, that burning desire to assert his enough-ness was on display He would make sure no challenge placed before him would ever make him feel like that again Driven and determined to succeed The "not-enough-ness" Jordan endured during his childhood would haunt him throughout his career, but he was able to channel that into an unnatural and unbelievably powerful inner drive at rare drive, paired with his natural athleticism, parted his challenges like water by a speedboat and left them fallen in his wake
Feel free to ask any more dental questions you might have.

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
Could you tell me more about the 'Not-Enough' Superpower, as mentioned in the article A Voice In The Arena?

The 'Not-Enough' Superpower, as discussed in the article A Voice In The Arena, refers to the burning desire to prove one's worth, often driven by childhood experiences. In the case of Michael Jordan, this superpower stemmed from his relationship with his father, who would often put him down and belittle him in front of his brothers.

As a result, Jordan internalized a 'chase for enough-ness' in the eyes of the most important man in his world. Throughout his basketball career, this 'not-enough-ness' drove him to succeed and channel his inner drive to overcome challenges. This powerful inner drive, combined with his natural athleticism, helped him achieve greatness and leave his challenges behind.

[Tag: A Voice In The Arena: The ‘Not-Enough’ Superpower]

What's the story behind Dental Office Culture: Many, Happy Returns?

It won’t happen overnight, so don’t set yourself up for disappointment with unrealistic expectations—or, worse, quickly decide that "culture doesn’t work" and abandon the process Culture always works as a component of your financial plan—the question is, does your current culture work for you or against you The investments you put into designing and building a winning culture that works for you will provide a highly positive return over the life of your practice Author Bio Jay Geier is an authority on growing independent practices His passion is in turning practices into businesses, doctors into CEOs and employees into high-performing individuals and teams

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
Can you tell me about Dental Office Culture: Many, Happy Returns?

Dental Office Culture: Many, Happy Returns is a concept developed by Jay Geier, an authority on growing independent practices. Geier's passion is in turning practices into businesses, doctors into CEOs, and employees into high-performing individuals and teams.

The idea revolves around creating a performance-based culture that drives business results. The culture should include training dates, regular recognition events, fun activities, benchmark meetings, and monthly and quarterly goals. This approach helps tie culture to performance and ensures that the culture works for you and not against you.

Geier is the founder and CEO of Scheduling Institute, a firm that specializes in training and development, and coaching doctors on these concepts. For a limited time, SI is giving Townies a free Blind Spot Analysis. For more information, visit [SI's website]([SI's website](http://SI's website)).

For any further dental advice or questions, I'm always available.

[Tag: Dental Office Culture: Many, Happy Returns]

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
Can you tell me about AI, GA4, SMS, and more in the context of dental marketing?

Certainly! AI tools like ChatGPT can be quite useful in dental marketing. They excel at keyword research and can generate a wide range of relevant keywords to help refine your SEO strategy. Here are some prompts to get you started:

- Please generate a list of 10 relevant keywords about orthodontics for adults.
- Kindly produce a set of 50 keywords that are commonly associated with the subject of orthodontics.
- I would like you to generate a set of 50 keywords closely related to orthodontics for children ages 7-10.

AI can also aid in content creation. While it can’t replace the human touch, AI-driven tools can generate drafts, provide content ideas, and assist with copywriting tasks. Here are some use cases for ChatGPT content/idea creation:

- Blog and article writing
- Social media content ideas
- Social media captions and hashtags
- Social media video script recommendations
- Email nurture series outline
- Email copywriting
- SMS nurture series outline
- SMS copywriting

The quality of the output of the AI tool depends largely on the prompt provided. When it comes to content or idea creation, consider framing all prompts using the following template:

- In a minute, I’m going to ask you to write some copy for my business. This will include blog content, Instagram posts with hashtags, sales emails, and email nurture campaigns.
- Ask me at least 20 questions about our orthodontic practice, patients, audience, and anything else you need to complete the tasks to the best of your ability.

Dental partner events are also important. With so many people being time-poor, events are a great way to connect with the wider community in a scalable and meaningful way.

Please don't hesitate to ask if you have more questions.

[Tag: AI, GA4, SMS and More]

messages.text: Do you have an opinion on Training Champions?

Understanding how a person likes to send and receive information and instructions, perform tasks and solve problems will go a long way in helping you determine the right role for them They might perform well enough in other roles, but will be most efficient, effective, stress-free and satisfied in the role that matches their strengths and work style Larger practices have a greater variety of roles and, therefore, more flexibility when it comes to finding a potentially better seat But even small practices can tweak job descriptions to better match an employee’s strengths, or adapt processes in a way that allows them to perform at their personal best
If you need clarification or more details, just let me know.
What's the story behind Training Champions?

Offering other seats also equates to providing developmental opportunities—important for both recruitment and retention—such as special projects and assignments, new responsibilities and team leadership roles As the business grows and expands, you’ll have strong in-house candidates to fill new seats, reducing the need for external hiring Team training Let’s say you’ve successfully filled your bus with all good people (which would have inevitably meant you had to eject some people from the bus to make room for stronger talent), and have gotten each person into their ideal seat
Is there anything else you'd like to know about dental care or any related topics?
What's next?

They all bring positive individual traits such as trustworthy character, enthusiasm and positivity, self-motivation, reliability, a strong work ethic and a sense of accountability Here, however, is where practice owners fall short of the finish line in terms of developing their team into the best it could be You assume good people will intuitively know what the most effective processes and best practices are, how to coordinate and communicate with teammates for optimal execution, how to satisfy patients based on what’s important to them and how to help drive business results A collection of high performers does not constitute a high-performing team They must be trained and developed to work together as a unit, all pulling in the same direction toward the same goals
Any other questions? Just ask and I am here to help!

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
What is your opinion on Training Champions?

Training Champions involves understanding the individual preferences and work styles of your team members. By identifying their strengths and matching them to suitable roles, you can help them become more efficient, effective, and satisfied in their work.\n\nIn larger practices, this can be easier due to the variety of roles available. However, even small practices can adjust job descriptions and work processes to better suit their employees' strengths.
Can you tell me more about the story behind Training Champions?

Training Champions is about offering developmental opportunities for your team members, such as special projects, new responsibilities, and team leadership roles. This approach is important for both recruitment and retention.

As the business grows, having strong in-house candidates to fill new positions can reduce the need for external hiring. However, it's not enough to simply gather high-performing individuals. They must be trained and developed to work together as a cohesive, goal-oriented team.

[Tag: Training Champions]

chat.topic: Embrace Progress: Treating Transfer Patients with Respect Earns Rewards
chat.tag: Embrace Progress: Treating Transfer Patients with Respect Earns Rewards

messages.text: What's the story behind Embrace Progress: Treating Transfer Patients with Respect Earns Rewards?

Many years ago, back in the golden age, orthodontists enjoyed a legalized monopoly (Some say we still do ) All you needed was a state-mandated education to get a state-issued license and practice in an area with a relative shortage of providers But, with Smile Direct Club and other disruptors getting in our faces—and, more importantly, our wallets—life is not so simple anymore At one point, we enjoyed the respect of most everyone Our profession was easily in the top 10 earning and regarded vocations in countless polls published in national magazines
Ready to assist with any more dental queries!
Feel free to expand on that

All the parents of children who played sports and danced with mine wanted their kids to become orthodontists (I know it was only because I showed up on time for practice and was rarely called away because of a beeper going off during an event or big game ) How did we get to that vaunted position I'll be the first to admit that one of the first hires an orthodontic practice makes—or if it doesn't, it should be—is in sales and marketing
I'm ready to help with any additional dental inquiries you have.
What's the story behind Embrace Progress: Treating Transfer Patients with Respect Earns Rewards?

Just like a Supreme Court justice (the most celebrated profession when I was in middle school), being recognized as a respected professional requires a certain type of behavior What behavior allowed for a profession or trade to become respected or placed above others Integrity comes to mind—integrity being defined as the quality of being honest and having strong moral principles; moral uprightness Are we practicing like this today Just as I railed against being a product pusher rather than a principled provider in a previous column, certain things come to mind, like second opinions and transfer patients, that can strengthen our position in our communities and in the eyes of our patients Look at orthodontists' websites, including my own, and you'll see that the view of transfer and second-opinion patients has changed
Need more help? I'm just a message away!

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
Can you tell me the story behind Embrace Progress: Treating Transfer Patients with Respect Earns Rewards?

Certainly! In the golden age of orthodontics, practitioners held a legalized monopoly and enjoyed the respect of many. This was a time when being an orthodontist was considered one of the top 10 earning and regarded vocations in numerous polls.

The profession was highly respected, with parents encouraging their children to become orthodontists. The key to achieving this esteemed position was a strong focus on sales and marketing.

However, with the emergence of disruptors like Smile Direct Club, the landscape has changed. Orthodontists now face competition and must adapt to new challenges.

In order to maintain and strengthen our position in our communities, it's essential to uphold the principles of integrity, honesty, and strong moral principles. This includes treating transfer patients and offering second opinions with respect and fairness.

By doing so, we can continue to build trust and respect within our communities and in the eyes of our patients.

[Tag: Embrace Progress: Treating Transfer Patients with Respect Earns Rewards]

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
Can you tell me about a complex restoration case you have worked on?

Certainly! We had a case involving a patient who required extensive restorative work on both the maxillary and mandibular arches. The treatment included IPS onlays, crowns, veneers, and full Katana zirconia bridges. The entire process was completed over seven appointments, with two weeks between each session. The patient was extremely comfortable throughout the treatment and even fell asleep during one of the appointments. After the completion of the treatment, the patient expressed great satisfaction with the results and felt more confident professionally, socially, and functionally. The case was particularly special because we were able to provide the patient with a healthy, attractive smile while ensuring their comfort and relaxation throughout the process.\n\n[Tag: Show Your Work: A Complex Restoration]
